comments.commentBody: I'm fine with hitting pharmaceuticals with a one two punch.  First, forbid them from direct to consumer advertising.  Then, have the government negotiate the price of all drugs, similar to what is done in other industrialized nations.  It will not cure all of our healthcare cost issues, but is sure to make a reasonable dent.  What is happening in this country is simply unsustainable.
I feel the same way, but as long as the United States is essentially run by corporations, nothing shall change.

This is a regular feature in the NYT, and many unusual diagnoses have been featured.  I'm certain that Dr. Sanders gets the permission of the patients whose cases she reviews for these interesting, and educational, articles.
Please.  Cleaning up?  The President has made disastrous decisions on his own.  He has been in office for some time.  Responsibility, please!
Excuse me, but HRC is as bellicose as they come.

This is why Biden should run. It was obvious to him ten years ago that Iraq should be partitioned. He also had the courage to say that we should fight a small, counter terrorism mission in Afghanistan, unlike his cynical boss who "split the difference" with a trendy faux counter insurgency campaign he never intended to see through from the moment he signed on to it.
The generals should have resigned the second the Afghan troop drawdowns were timed to coincide with American election campaigns, as it was clear they didn't have the political commitment to win the war in Afghanistan. We didn't need Marines in Helmand to find Bin Laden, it could have been accomplished just the same under Biden's alternative.
It's more obvious in retrospect, but was clear then too, that we weren't determined to defeat the Taliban, since we weren't going to pressure Pakistan in any serious way.
Having said all that, our forces fought with distinction and honor over these last fifteen years, and gave various peoples of the Middle East the chance to build better, Islamist free societies. With the exception of the Kurds they have chosen not to.
What motivates people to fight in Western Asia? Allah or ethnicity, or maybe both. We can't make them fight for states they don't believe in.
There were people who were right at crucial points in the past, like Biden, and we need to reward them.
After the Soviet Union imploded I warned friends not to gloat too much because it would happen to us too; several decades later. It's an inevitable consequence of empire.

Glad to see I'm not the only one who's noticed this:

"The US spent a lot of time laughing at the Soviet Union for getting embroiled in Afghanistan but we've allowed ourselves to be sucked into a similar situation..."

Exactly. And while the Soviet Union was there a long time, we've now been there much longer.

Are these the only two choices?

"... the only alternative to using these proxies is to send US troops back into combat and there is no general enthusiasm for that either in the administration or amongst the public at large."

If proxies won't do, and there's no enthusiasm for sending in our own troops, is there a third choice -- such as staying out of it entirely?

"The age of hard power is gone. Can we just concentrate on building soft power?"

If people in other countries hate you because you try to impose "hard power" on them, your chances of building "soft power" drop considerably.

We also live in a very judgemental, highly critical society that belonged to our parents and people of my generation only to continue to be handed down. So I believe that these kids have legitimate concerns if they are being judged harshly at every turn per your comment.  I hope you don't have any pets and if you do, they are properly cared for and not with a "livestock" mentality.

Children Pee and Defecate into diapers and their hands are germ factories, but you have no problem with them touching your delicate organic produce.

FYI, your precious farmers market fruits and vegetables are grown in feces.

In NYC, they bring them into supermarkets and many coops have problems with owners bringing their dogs into the common gardens, where they urinate and defecate while the owners pretend this is not happening, so they do not have to clean it up.

Despicable narcissism they then teach to their spoiled children.

Every week I go to the Farmer's Market and every week I see people walking with their dogs, even though there is a large sign at the entrance of the market specifically stating that no dogs are allowed in the market due to health reasons. Dogs pee and defecate -- why on earth would we want that next to our produce?

Yet perfectly healthy people bring their dogs into a place where they're not allowed.

What a selfish, self-absorbed, me-me-me society we've become.

There is no evidence that what you suggest was not tried.  It does appear that her doctor(s) was negligent, but we don't have all the facts.  She might not have been insistent enough that she needed further treatment either.  Patients (and in some cases, family members) need to be their own advocates.

"They hate us for our freedom" is neocon mantra.

Such conceit is the core of "American Exceptionalism".

Who can forget George W. Bush's explanation for why people in other countries don't like the US government?

"They hate us for our freedom."

I remember my reaction to that statement, fairly summarized as:

"Huh?"

I doubt a single human being who's lived in the Middle East in the last 50 years has attacked any of us because they resent our being free. They just want us to leave them alone. Why is that so hard to see? Why is it so hard to do just that?
do i chop up the dried chilies or leave it in whole?
Could be worse, his behavior could be dictated by an algorithm.

Don't want to call someone a liar?

How about: "Fiorina Cites Non-Existant Video"?

You can find all kinds of media containing all sorts of grisly human demise. What you can't find is a video containing what the less than successful former CEO described. Without a smoking gun, you can't say liar, but you can say her statement was not true. And that should have been front and center.

Beth, I agree with you, but the issue is not what conclusions I have drawn or you have drawn regarding Fiorina's statements and actions. The question is what the Times should report. They should report just exactly what you said here: that after she was told that the video was heavily doctored, not anything to do with PP, and was a stillborn, she still maintained her narrative. Exactly. Readers are still perfectly capable of making their own interpretations of those facts.

The possibility still remains that she is confused, drunk, stupid, or delusional.

Do I think that's the case? No. But I appreciate the New York Times sticking to the facts, in news articles (editorials are a different matter).
OK, I get it. But I really find it hard to digest that no one in the news ever calls a lie, a lie. They say " falsehood, untruth" or any manner of fancy ways around what it is.

That's one reason I really like Politifact's rating system: True, Mostly True, Half-True, Mostly False, False, Pants on Fire.

The Pants on Fire rating is reserved for situations where a source has had every reason to know something is false and is saying it anyways. For example, Ben Carson saying that Margaret Sanger believed in aborting black babies as a method of eugenics was rated "False", but a chart that completely falsely suggested that Planned Parenthood performed more abortions than women's health services in 2013 was rated "Pants on Fire" because not only was it wrong it was obviously wrong and intentionally misleading.

The reason most high-level news sources will avoid the word "lie" as much as possible is that it is a judgment call. Okay, before people get even more upset, remember, I personally think Fiorina was lying. But I am personally also very capable of coming to that conclusion without being led there.

The idea is to stick as close as possible to the FACTS. And nothing but the facts. The fact is the videos show one thing; Carly Fiorina described them as showing another.

But to call that a "lie" is to make a judgment call; to go beyond the facts. A "lie" is when someone knowingly conceals or distorts the facts. To be sure it is a lie you would have to be inside Carly Fiorina's head. She may not be a liar. She may be confused. She may have misremembered what she saw. She may have been hallucinating. She may be too stupid to understand what she was seeing. She may be mentally ill. Or she may be an out-out liar. But all of those are INTERPRETATIONS of the facts - they're not facts the Times has direct access to. All the Times has direct access to is what the videos show - because anyone can watch them - and what Fiorina said - which is on record.

Again, I fully concur with virtually everyone here that she is a liar. My personal opinion of Carly Fiorina is that she is basically a predator. I find her loathsome. But I'm fully capable of reaching those conclusions based on REPORTING of what she has said and done, and comparing what she has said and done with reported facts.

My doctors assumed I would get information from the internet to learn about my cancer and the many side effects of its treatment.  They didn't mind, but were happy that I ran it all by them to sort out what actually applied to my case (for instance, they were not eager to tell me the stage of my cancer, but when I tried to do it myself with online information, they were quick to straighten me out--it was III, not IV).
I think that whisky would not be clean enough. Vodka takes on the flavor of whatever it is in, where whisky has a deeper flavor and is a bit sweet.
It's just 1/4 tsp of oil rubbed on each potato. It will not make a mess in the oven and wrapping in foil would allow them to steam, not bake.
The skins will not be crisp if you wrap them in foil.
If you wrap the potato in foil, then bake it, the best adjustment is to feed it to the chickens.  Maybe they will eat it.  The potato, not the foil.
Doesn't the olive oil make for a mess in the oven? What adjustment if I wrap each in foil? Thanks
People are nuts in this country. Any movie star should take their safety very seriously. In fact, I would probably move overseas.

"Depending on your perspective, the opening minutes of the premiere... were either the boldest thing 'The Leftovers' has done so far, or the flat-out craziest."

Or, option C: A pretentious lift from '2001: A Space Odyssey.'
I feared this taking place .. metal detectors at all points of public access. People will retreat further into their devices

Is there no way that the NYTimes can stop calling the New York State Theatre by the name it has acquired because of a donation from those despicable billionaires? I want to throw up every time I see that name.
Probably for the same reason they decided to ignore Penny Dreadful's second season. It's still listed here in Artsbeat. Apparently we're led to believe it's still a current recap.
Ahhh, the second Season of Penny Dreadful?  Was anything but dreadful.  It was terrific.
Scandal? Seriously?
just curious, why doesn't arts beat cover Scandal. Surely there's a lot of plump material there!
I believe Nina Hoss (Astrid) was in an earlier Homeland episode as well.    IMDb credits her with an appearance in 2014.
Quinn's old flame?

when Carrie was trying to find Quinn (season 4), Quinn was hiding out at Astrid's place and making a bomb he intended to plant under a street grate to kill Haqqanni.  Astrid initially covered for Quinn (to Carrie) and we got the impression that they had been an item in the past.  In the season 4 finale, when everyone was at Carrie's sister's house for the post-funeral party, Carrie is relieved to see that Quinn has made it back alive.   When she asked him how he got out, Quinn replies, "German intelligence (ie Astrid) was helpful."

The first lesson of Homeland is  - don't sleep with Carrie. She's this century's Ben Cartwright, so let's see how long her German boy-toy survives. Carrie's tete-a-tete with Al Amin - and it seems a bit cutesy close to el alamein for a German set story - almost plays like Keira Knightley requesting a pirate's parlay. Just how many episodes before Quinn opens that box and finds Carrie's picture in an envelope? (PS For the few of us who sat thru A Most Wanted Man, it seems that Nina Hoss is continuing her role as a German Intelligence type.)
